Question.title: ?Macroscopic Evaluation of Mesorectum (required for rectal cancers) (Note C)

ListItem.name: LI_38115
ListItem.title: Sessile serrated adenoma / sessile serrated polyp

ListItem.name: LI_34223
ListItem.title: No viable cancer cells (complete response, score 0)

ListItem.name: LI_34224
ListItem.title: Single cells or rare small groups of cancer cells (near complete response, score 1)

ListItem.name: LI_34225
ListItem.title: Residual cancer with evident tumor regression, but more than single cells or rare small groups of cancer cells (partial response, score 2)

ListItem.name: LI_34226
ListItem.title: Extensive residual cancer with no evident tumor regression (poor or no response, score 3)

ListItem.name: LI_5790
ListItem.title: No lymph nodes submitted or found

Section.name: S_1486
Section.title: PATHOLOGIC STAGE CLASSIFICATION (pTNM, AJCC 8th Edition) (Note L)

DisplayedItem.name: DI_44119
DisplayedItem.title: Note: Reporting of pT, pN, and (when applicable) pM categories is based on information available to the pathologist at the time the report is issued. As per the AJCC (Chapter 1, 8th Ed.) it is the managing physician’s responsibility to establish the final pathologic stage based upon all pertinent information, including but potentially not limited to this pathology report.

Property.name: p_rptTxt_44119_1
Property.val: Note: Reporting of pT, pN, and (when applicable) pM categories is based on information available to the pathologist at the time the report is issued. As per the AJCC (Chapter 1, 8th Ed.) it is the managing physician’s responsibility to establish the final pathologic stage based upon all pertinent information, including but potentially not limited to this pathology report.

ListItem.name: LI_37628
ListItem.title: pTX: Primary tumor cannot be assessed

ListItem.name: LI_37629
ListItem.title: pT0: No evidence of primary tumor

ListItem.name: LI_37630
ListItem.title: pTis: Carcinoma in situ, intramucosal carcinoma (involvement of lamina propria with no extension through muscularis mucosae)

ListItem.name: LI_37631
ListItem.title: pT1: Tumor invades the submucosa (through the muscularis mucosa but not into the muscularis propria)

ListItem.name: LI_37632
ListItem.title: pT2: Tumor invades the muscularis propria

ListItem.name: LI_37633
ListItem.title: pT3: Tumor invades through the muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues

DisplayedItem.name: DI_45111
DisplayedItem.title: pT4: Tumor invades the visceral peritoneum or invades or adheres to adjacent organ or structure

ListItem.name: LI_37635
ListItem.title: pT4a: Tumor invades# through the visceral peritoneum (including gross perforation of the bowel through tumor and continuous invasion of tumor through areas of inflammation to the surface of the visceral peritoneum)

ListItem.name: LI_37636
ListItem.title: pT4b: Tumor directly invades# or adheres## to adjacent organs or structures

DisplayedItem.name: DI_54262
DisplayedItem.title: # Direct invasion in T4 includes invasion of other organs or other segments of the colorectum as a result of direct extension through the serosa, as confirmed on microscopic examination (for example, invasion of the sigmoid colon by a carcinoma of the cecum) or, for cancers in a retroperitoneal or subperitoneal location, direct invasion of other organs or structures by virtue of extension beyond the muscularis propria (i.e., respectively, a tumor on the posterior wall of the descending colon invading the left kidney or lateral abdominal wall; or a mid or distal rectal cancer with invasion of prostate, seminal vesicles, cervix, or vagina).

DisplayedItem.name: DI_57505
DisplayedItem.title: ## Tumor that is adherent to other organs or structures, grossly, is classified cT4b. However, if no tumor is present in the adhesion, microscopically, the classification should be pT1-4a depending on the anatomical depth of wall invasion. The V and L classification should be used to identify the presence or absence of vascular or lymphatic invasion whereas the PN prognostic factor should be used for perineural invasion.

ListItem.name: LI_37638
ListItem.title: pNX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

ListItem.name: LI_37639
ListItem.title: pN0: No regional lymph node metastasis

DisplayedItem.name: DI_46591
DisplayedItem.title: pN1: One to three regional lymph nodes are positive (tumor in lymph nodes measuring >= 0.2 mm), or any number of tumor deposits are present and all identifiable lymph nodes are negative

ListItem.name: LI_37640
ListItem.title: pN1a: One regional lymph node is positive

ListItem.name: LI_37641
ListItem.title: pN1b: Two or three regional lymph nodes are positive

ListItem.name: LI_37642
ListItem.title: pN1c: No regional lymph nodes are positive, but there are tumor deposits in the subserosa, mesentery, nonperitonealized pericolic or perirectal / mesorectal tissues

DisplayedItem.name: DI_55290
DisplayedItem.title: pN2: Four or more regional nodes are positive

ListItem.name: LI_37644
ListItem.title: pN2a: Four to six regional lymph nodes are positive

ListItem.name: LI_37645
ListItem.title: pN2b: Seven or more regional lymph nodes are positive

ListItem.name: LI_37648
ListItem.title: ?Not applicable - pM cannot be determined from the submitted specimen(s)

Property.name: p_rptTxt_37648_1
Property.val: Not applicable - pM cannot be determined from the submitted specimen(s)

DisplayedItem.name: DI_43637
DisplayedItem.title: pM1: Metastasis to one or more distant sites or organs or peritoneal metastasis is identified

ListItem.name: LI_37650
ListItem.title: pM1a: Metastasis to one site or organ is identified without peritoneal metastasis

ListItem.name: LI_37651
ListItem.title: pM1b: Metastasis to two or more sites or organs is identified without peritoneal metastasis

ListItem.name: LI_37653
ListItem.title: pM1c: Metastasis to the peritoneal surface is identified alone or with other site or organ metastases

ListItem.name: LI_1573
ListItem.title: Dysplasia arising in inflammatory bowel disease

DisplayedItem.name: DI_30211
DisplayedItem.title: Note: For reporting molecular testing and immunohistochemistry for mismatch repair proteins, and for other cancer biomarker testing results, the CAP Colorectal Biomarker Template should be used. Pending biomarker studies should be listed in the Comments section of this report.
